content:
The shift towards online shopping has been a significant factor in the decline of physical retail stores. The convenience and speed of online shopping, combined with the ability to compare prices and read reviews, have made it more appealing to consumers. Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated this trend, as many people have been forced to stay at home and have increasingly turned to online shopping. As a result, physical retail stores have struggled to compete with the lower overhead costs of online businesses, which often allow for lower prices and greater selection.

According to a report from Coresight Research, an estimated 10,000 physical retail stores in the United States are expected to close in 2021, which would be a record high. This follows a trend in recent years of widespread store closures, with many well-known brands such as Sears, J.C. Penney, and Toys "R" Us going bankrupt and closing their stores. This has had a significant impact on the job market, as many retail workers have lost their jobs due to store closures.

However, while the trend towards online shopping is undeniable, physical retail stores are not necessarily going away completely. Some businesses are finding success by combining their physical stores with online sales, in a model known as "omnichannel" retailing. By offering the best of both worlds, physical stores can provide a more immersive and tactile shopping experience, while online sales can offer convenience and accessibility. In order to survive, physical retail stores will need to continue to adapt and find new ways to compete in an increasingly digital world.

Reference:

* Coresight Research: "US Store Closures in 2021: An Unprecedented Year for Retail?" (<https://coresight.com/research/us-store-closures-in-2021-an-unprecedented-year-for-retail/>)
